com.bigdata.rdf.sail.webapp

Interface ConfigParams


  • public interface ConfigParams
    Interface declaring the config-params understood by the BigdataRDFServletContextListener.

    Note: When used in a jini/River configuration, the name of the component for those configuration options is the fully qualified class name for the NanoSparqlServer.

    See Also:
    Change web.xml parameter names to be consistent with Jini/River

      static String WARMUP_TIMEOUT
      When non-zero, this specifies the timeout (milliseconds) for a warmup period when the NSS starts up (warmup is disabled when this is ZERO).

    • Field Detail

      • PROPERTY_FILE

        static final String PROPERTY_FILE
        The property file (for a standalone bigdata instance) or the jini configuration file (for a bigdata federation). The file must end with either ".properties" or ".config". This parameter is ignored if the IIndexManager is specified as an attribute of the web application context.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NAMESPACE

        static final String NAMESPACE
        The default bigdata namespace of for the triple or quad store instance to be exposed (default DEFAULT_NAMESPACE). Note that there can be many triple or quad store instances within a bigdata instance.
        See Also:

      • DEFAULT_QUERY_THREAD_POOL_SIZE

        static final int DEFAULT_QUERY_THREAD_POOL_SIZE
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • FORCE_OVERFLOW

        static final String FORCE_OVERFLOW
        Force a compacting merge of all shards on all data services in a bigdata federation (optional, default false). This option should only be used for benchmarking purposes.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • READ_LOCK

        static final String READ_LOCK
        The commit time against which the server will assert a read lock by holding open a read-only transaction against that commit point (optional). When given, queries will default to read against this commit point. Otherwise queries will default to read against the most recent commit point on the database. Regardless, each query will be issued against a read-only transaction.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DESCRIBE_EACH_NAMED_GRAPH

        static final String DESCRIBE_EACH_NAMED_GRAPH
        When true and the KB instance is in the quads mode, each named graph will also be described in in the same level of detail as the default graph (default false). Otherwise only the default graph will be described.

        Note: I have changed the default to false since this operation can be long-running for messy web graphs such as the TBL six degrees of freedom crawl. We wind up with one named graph for each "friend", which is a lot of named graphs, plus there are a lot of predicates that show up in web data. Together, this makes the per-named graph response not a very good default. However, you can certainly enable this if you only have a reasonable number of named graphs and/or only expose the SPARQL end point to a limited audience.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DEFAULT_DESCRIBE_EACH_NAMED_GRAPH

        static final boolean DEFAULT_DESCRIBE_EACH_NAMED_GRAPH
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • READ_ONLY

        static final String READ_ONLY
        When true, requests will be refused for mutation operations on the database made through the REST API. This may be used to help lock down a public facing interface.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DEFAULT_READ_ONLY

        static final boolean DEFAULT_READ_ONLY
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • QUERY_TIMEOUT

        static final String QUERY_TIMEOUT
        When non-zero, this specifies the timeout (milliseconds) for a query. This may be used to limit resource consumption on a public facing interface.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • DEFAULT_QUERY_TIMEOUT

        static final long DEFAULT_QUERY_TIMEOUT
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • WARMUP_TIMEOUT

        static final String WARMUP_TIMEOUT
        When non-zero, this specifies the timeout (milliseconds) for a warmup period when the NSS starts up (warmup is disabled when this is ZERO).
        See Also:
        pre-heat the journal on startup , Constant Field Values

      • WARMUP_NAMESPACE_LIST

        static final String WARMUP_NAMESPACE_LIST
        A comma delimited list of namespaces to be processed during the warmup procedure (optional). When not specified, ALL namespaces will be processed.
        See Also:
        pre-heat the journal on startup , Constant Field Values
